Trump hasn't been within 5 points of Biden since April and continues to lag behind by around 8 points. He quit the second debate and isn't likely to bring in additional support through rallies, has no plan for combatting the pandemic despite having COVID himself, and is ramming through a Supreme Court Justice despite the majority of Americans saying whoever is elected in November should get the nom. He continues to attack voters and popular lawmakers and appears to have no strategy with just three weeks left until election day.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Michigan by 5.3 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.2% for trump to Biden's 49.3%. Seven day momentum was in Biden's favor, improving his position by 0.9%.

Biden has been at +8 in polling averages as election day has been going on for 2 weeks now in Michigan, as almost 1 in 5 of the number of ballots cast in 2016 have already been cast: 
https://targetearly.targetsmart.com/?view_type=State&demo=Age&demo_val=All&state=MI Not enough time for Trump to turn all this around and get into the significant lead that he would need to come back from behind.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

Most recent polling has Biden up 11, his largest lead since mid-August. This may be an outlier but it confirms Biden continues to have a significant lead in the state.

In 2016, Donald Trump unexpectedly won Michigan by a narrow margin of 0.23%. As things are looking far less rosy for Trump in 2020, Michigan is as close a "shoo-in" for Biden as it gets. Biden and affiliated Democrats have outspent Republicans by $4 million in Michigan
https://www.axios.com/biden-trump-summer-ad-strategy-de91bde7-81c5-4642-9314-a93a2b83c224.html

Biden is running 6-12 points ahead consistently [1,2]. Democrats in MI, though, have learned the lesson of 2016 and are not taking the polls at face value [3], with talk to keep pushing through to voters, as the favorability is running about even. I'm bumping up slightly on Biden. [1]  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/michigan/

Updating my prediction to reflect Biden's consistent 7-8 percentage point lead. While his lead has shrunk from around 9.5 to 10 in recent months, it hasn't dropped below a 7 point advantage since very early June. Moreover, he hasn't been polled below Trump for the entirety of 538's polling period (beginning in February). This, when combined with Michigan's largely Democratic voting history (mentioned in an earlier post) and the very narrow margin of victory for Trump in 2016, is looking more and more like a blue state in 2020.
@trump will make mincemeat of @Biden in the TV debates. Michigan is mid-west post industrial let down by establishment politics and they'll vote Trump again.

Biden's polling lead has gone down slightly, so adjusting this down to 95%. NYT today reporting that Trump Campaign is almost not even advertising in Michigan, yikes! https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/29/us/politics/michigan-trump-biden-2020.html
No change from previous rationale; decided to extremize my prediction.

Since George H.W. Bush, Michigan has gone Democratic in every election until Trump, usually by over 5 percentage points. They swung narrowly to Trump in 2016, but have since polled towards Biden consistently. With national numbers painting an even bleaker picture, and their refusal to side with a losing Republican since 1968, it is very unlikely Michigan will back Donald Trump.

Close in 2016, Trump is performing poorly in polls nationally and in Michigan, Biden being an old white male will bring advantages in some voting demographics. However an improved economy or big turnaround in covid-19 could bring trump victory
The goodwill shown in 2016 to the outside almost certainly has gone so without a major change Trump is unlikely to win this state.

July 26th: Consistent lead in opinion polls [1] about 7-9%
[1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/michigan/

In deciding the likelihood of either the (R) Republican or (D) Democratic Presidential Candidates winning Michigan in the 2020 Presidential Election I used -> X = X(outside) * W(outside) + X(inside) * W(inside)
W(outside) + W(inside) = 1
W(outside), W(inside) = [0 - 1.0]
X(outside), X(inside) = [0 - 100%] Given the Republican & Democratic Dominance in Michigan I will assume that ->
Other Party = 0% Outside refers to previous Michigan Presidential election outcomes and Inside refers to the specific circumstances of the 2020 Michigan Presidential Election. Post WWII, Michigan has voted 9 times Democratic and 9 times Republican in the US Presidential Elections from 1948 - 2016 ->
D(outside) = 50% = 9/18
R(outside) = 50% = 9/18 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_wall_(politics)#In_presidential_elections   Looking Inside, Michigan is near universally predicted as leaning Democratic for 2020 -> 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election_in_Michigan#Predictions  Averaging these predictions I get ->
D(inside) = 63.75%
R(inside) = 36.25% = 100% - 63.75% In choosing the weighting between Outside and Inside, I decided that ->
W(outside) << W(inside) 
           0.25 << 0.75 Why I chose this was that in 2016, Democrats had a weak candidate, a poor economic message who were complacent with Michigan combined with Trump investing heavily in the state resulting in Republicans winning the popular vote extremely narrowly. 
In 2020, Trump is presiding over an economy in recession and a failed ability in controlling the pandemic. Additionally, Joe Biden I believe understands and is more in touch with Midwest voters' concerns like in Michigan than Clinton and won't be making the same mistake again. Also Democrats in the 2018 midterms made very strong gains in retaking seats from Republicans throughout Michigan ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Michigan   All this makes me conclude that Michigan in the 2020 Presidential Election will be less a swing state as shown with Outside but more a likely Democratic Presidential state as has been in recent Presidential elections as expressed with Inside.
From this I calculated that ->
D = 60% = 50% * 0.25 + 63.75% * 0.75 
R = 40% = 50% * 0.25 + 36.25% * 0.75 Given these percentages are relatively mild, I will push these values more to their respective extremes ->
D = 75% = 60% * 1.25
R = 25% = 100% - 75% Democratic Win in Michigan for 2020 Presidential Election = 75%
Republican Win in Michigan for 2020 Presidential Election = 25%
Other Win in Michigan for 2020 Presidential Election = 0%
D candidate has maintained a steady lead beyond the margin of error in high quality polls for over two months.
Polls favor Biden.  Democratic gov there gives Dems an advantage.  It went for trump in 16, but a lot of buyers remorse since then.
Updates, based on the recent polls

Expect that public distaste if continuing BLM protests will self-suppress Dem votes.  While they can’t bring themselves to vote for Trump, they will stay home.
Michigan has a Dem Governor who is extremely successful in fighting Covid-19.
While polling behind Biden, polls and approval ratings aren’t votes. The backlash on strict lockdowns may play out in his favor.

Ok, so we all know Michigan went red for the first time since '88 in 2016. So right off the bat I'm inclined to give Trump a higher chance than most here. But, nearly all reputable polls have Biden ahead in MI by a healthy margin (538 has him around +10 avg; RCP has +7.5). For comparison, Hillary was +3.6 on election week and lost by 0.3 in Michigan. That was a normal polling error.  If Biden's lead holds, there would need to be one of the largest polling errors we've seen in order for Trump to overcome it. So, Biden clearly has the lead here. But, I'm banking on the race tightening and the result becoming less certain in this state.

The 5% chance I am giving Trump is only based on the remote possibility that he will somehow find a way to hack the data and steal the election.
The Democratic governor is going to pull down the ticket

Biden runs +11 on Siena College poll (A+poll) and is up +5 and +6 on two latest polls in June 30. Also, Covid-19 data fro Michigan are slowly starting to worsen (from +/- 150 a day a month ago to close to 400 a day now). This works against Trump
The polling has been fairly consistent for Biden and this would track with results from pre-2016 and 2018.

Reasons
1. Biden's strongest voting block is the white middle class men. 
2. MI manufacturing sector has been hard hit by the current economic downturn.
3, Unless there is a October miracle or health debacle for Biden, MI is strongly in Biden's favor.
4. The 30% for trump is my prediction is leaving room for a October debacle or a miracle vaccine.

current trends in economics, world trade, geopolitics, have left blue collar voters that brought Trump into office disenchanted.  Current state of racial tensions, and mood of the country trending away from focus on white centric agreement towards more equality will impact core swing constituents including white educated women, black voters, and other voters of color. Turn out will be key either way.

Current polling indicates a preference for Biden. Also Michigan was almost an even split between Trump and Clinton in 2016. Given current attitudes surrounding the President's handling of COVID19 and racial tensions, the Democratic nominee should win by a healthy margin.
2016 was the first election since 1988 that a Republican Presidental candidate won. 2016 the race was won by the GOP with less than 20k votes. 2020 Michigan will swing back to the DNC.

Biden is almost certain to be Democratic candidate and poor economy, poor handling of the pandemic, and poor appeal to independent voters give him a strong likelihood over almost certain Republican candidate Trump. "Someone else" may be elected given non-zero probability that Trump steps down or candidates expected become ill, but question phrased such that by my reading it would have to be someone from another party, reducing likelihood to near zero.

- Base 40-Year history is 50 - 50
- Since 1992 it's 85 - 15. 
       Weighted recent history more heavily.
- Biden has slight but consistent lead. Still a lot of time, though.
- "Someone else" isn't technically 0 but rounded to nearest 1%

Michigan was part of the "blue wall" from 1992 until 2016, when it switched to the republican vote. Due to COVID and civil issues within the united states currently, and voting history, I believe the vote will go democrat this time.

Thought I was being bullish by thinking 65%+ for Biden before looking at the crowd forecast. 538 shows a clear 10 point lead for Biden. RealClear Politics has +7.5. RCP has Clinton ahead by +8.3 in July 2016 and still lost. I do think that's unlikely to be repeated though; voters seem more decided this year than most, and Trump is particularly atrocious. There's still a fair amount of time left, however, so I don't think I'm ready to bet as high as 80%+.
Based on  research and how well the future campaigning, debates, stances, etc. will effect the outcome.

Trump’s poll numbers are underwater. Other presidents have been able to recover from such lows, including Trump himself in 2016, but it’s hard to imagine how things will change between now and the election. The damage caused by Trump’s response to the corona virus cannot be undone, nor can his decades of racist comments be reversed.  Trump runs best when he can play the part of a rogue outsider crashing an establishment party.  He excels at this because his nature is to attack in all situations (His most memorable campaign chant was “lock her up.”) . So, when Trump is the incumbent, defending a body count in excess of 125,000, it’s hard for him to just make fun of the virus on Twitter until it goes away. The coronavirus is not impressed with his social media habits.  There’s also a 5% chance that Trump might decline the nomination of the Republican Party, opt out of the 2020 race, and be replaced by Pence on the ticket. He would still be president just as Lyndon Johnson was still president when he opted not to run for re-election because of how he handled the Vietnam War.
Trumps files Supreme Court case regarding ACA.  Case comes to trial in October.  Trump loses in a landslide.
Biden has not lost a poll since to Trump since March and has won 17 in succession, the last three by double digits.

Trying something new... starting with a firm, decisive up/down vote initially and then getting more nuanced upon further reflection (per my discussion w/ @dowser.) 
That said, my Election 2020 record has been kind to me, so I don't want to reinvent the wheel too much.

Polls consistently show Biden (the presumptive Democratic candidate) ahead of Trump by an average of  7 - 11 points, since November https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/michigan/ - Note - I only have been using data generated by polls which are designated as A or A+ by 538. Furthermore, if you exclude the 2016 elections, Michigan has gone Democrat since 1992, beating the Republican nominee at a range of 3.42 points to 16.47 points with a median score of slightly more than 8 points (8.44) - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_elections_in_Michigan Furthermore, Donald Trump just barely eeked out a win in Michigan in 2016, beating Clinton by 0.22 of a percentage point, a difference of slightly over 10,000 votes.
This is how I read it now.

Biden is running 5-18 points ahead, consistently [1,2]. Reviewing the senate race, Peters is leading James consistently [3]. And with Trump winning by less than a point in 2016 [4], it seems like it will be an easy pickup for Biden. [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/michigan.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/michigan/

So early in the process to make a prediction.   Like 4 years ago it will come down to who will get out to vote.
At this time I believe worry about the virus is significantly stronger among Democrats to the extent that I believe 
it will be a factor in voter turn out.  It will be a close race in Michigan and if more Trump voters are willing to stand in line and vote than Biden voters then it will be a repeat win for Trump.   An unknown at this time is the VP selection by Biden.  If it is a black women then the enthusiasm in Detroit area could overcome the GOP voters turn out.
Biden is ahead in the polls and will likely win. I still feel this election is an indictment against Trump and he is not going to do well.

CNBC polls have stayed consistent over the last month with 48% Biden. Trump voters have moved away, but to other candidates, not to Biden. But what happens when the rubber meets the road, if they understand voting for a 3rd party gives Biden the win?  Interesting upcoming factors will include VP selection and conventions as well as whether Trump picks up union support.
